messageBody:
>So said Tharp, Joshua L, SOLGV on 2003-06-30 --------------------

[JBR]
>I don't understand why this is a problem. If your class implements three
>interfaces, then you have three test cases for that class, each a
>subclass of the corresponding abstract test for each interface. Run them
>all. No law says you must have one test case per production class, and
>in fact, you probably shouldn't!
>
>
[JLT]
>It's a simple matter of keeping the test tree as understandable as the
>source it is testing.

If you have tried both ways and encountered this problem, then great; otherwise, I suggest you resist the temptation to "keep the source simple" at the cost of doing what you need to do. xUnit users often make their test fixtures too complex because they want to adhere to "one test class per production class". The complex fixture with 50 tests is more difficult to navigate than five tests with simple fixtures and 10 tests each. This is my experience.

For the book I'm working on, I have the following three test fixtures for testing Java's Collection interface.

* BagTest
* EmptyBagTest
* HelloTwiceBagTest

Other than the somewhat obscure "hello twice bag" (a bag with the object "hello" in it twice), I think this is pretty easy to read. Do you find anything in those names that makes it difficult to understand what's tested where? The alternative is a bunch of test methods like:

* testEmpty_Empty
* testEmpty_HelloTwice
* testEmpty

A group of these per behavior to test. Such duplication is truly unnecessary and having multiple test fixtures is just as easy (if not easier) to read and understand.

Understand that I'm talking about the fear I sense you have about making the test code complex, and not attacking you or your ideas. The way I see it: either way, it's complex; but I think having many fixtures is less complex than one big monolithic fixture. If you favor cohesive production classes (and probably you do), then why not cohesive test fixtures?

>If there are too many test classes testing a
>single source class, it become difficult to look at a package for the
>first time and understand what is going on.

It may become difficult, but not if the tests are well named. The same is true for any code: complex code with bad names is difficult to read; complex code with good names is often not-that-difficult to read. Since the complexity is there either way, why not go down the path that allows the best names?

> The link that Paolo sent on
>an earlier post has a link showing the use of inner classes to organize
>the abstract test cases. The benefit is that I can enter a package, look
>for a single class WidgetTest.java and be able to track back all of the
>tests associated with Widget.java.

Agreed, and so using nested classes for related fixtures is not a bad idea at all. I just don't think that it's necessarily any clearer: it's just all in one file rather than in three.
